abstract: A quiet spring evening had descended upon the midtown Manhattan environs of the General Motors Building. But 25 floors up, as the carmaker and its advisers prepared its bankruptcy filing, the mood could be anything but calm.
snippet: A quiet spring evening had descended upon the midtown Manhattan environs of the General Motors Building. But 25 floors up, as the carmaker and its advisers prepared its bankruptcy filing, the mood could be anything but calm.
lead_paragraph: To nearly all passersby, the scene at 767 Fifth Avenue Sunday evening could not have been more mundane. The usual handfuls of tourist gawked at the gleaming cube atop the midtown Manhattan Apple Store. A slight but insistent breeze whipped up the front plaza’s fountains, glowing warmly in the deepening twilight.

headline.main: The Calm Before the G.M. Bankruptcy Filing

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: William R. Hambrecht, the veteran venture capitalist, spoke with The New York Times’s Holly Hubbard Preston about the changes he had seen during a 52-year career, and what he still hoped to accomplish.
snippet: William R. Hambrecht, the veteran venture capitalist, spoke with The New York Times’s Holly Hubbard Preston about the changes he had seen during a 52-year career, and what he still hoped to accomplish.
lead_paragraph: William R. Hambrecht helped usher in the high-technology age in the 1980s by being an early venture investor in Apple , Genentech and a host of other industry pioneers. Hambrecht & Quist, the investment firm he co-founded, was also the lead underwriter of many of the initial public stock offerings of these companies.

headline.main: The Man Who Shook Up Underwriting
